Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as there is no clear evidence or confirmation that the person in the video is indeed Guinean President Alpha Conde.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the scene in the video did not take place in Guinea, as confirmed by the correspondent who analyzed the license plates visible in the footage.
Exist alternative explanation: There is an alternative explanation that the video shows an unrelated incident, as evidenced by the presence of visual clues that match a video from 2015 showing a student-led strike at the National University of Equatorial Guinea.
Understate: The claim may understate the complexity of the situation by simplifying it to a single incident of the president attacking a minister, without considering other possible factors or motivations.
Exaggerate: There is no evidence to support the claim that the minister in the video stole COVID funds, which may be an exaggeration or unfounded assumption.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the video shows President Alpha Conde attacking a minister, without providing sufficient evidence or context to support this assumption.
Falters at times: The claim falters at times by presenting conflicting information and uncertainties, such as the unclear identity of the assailant and the location of the incident.
